section.title: About Primary Storage
section.para: Primary storage is associated with a cluster or (in KVM and VMware) a zone, and it stores the disk volumes for all the VMs running on hosts.

You can add multiple primary storage servers to a cluster or zone. At least one is required. It is typically located close to the hosts for increased performance. &PRODUCT; manages the allocation of guest virtual disks to particular primary storage devices.

It is useful to set up zone-wide primary storage when you want to avoid extra data copy operations. With cluster-based primary storage, data in the primary storage is directly available only to VMs within that cluster. If a VM in a different cluster needs some of the data, it must be copied from one cluster to another, using the zone's secondary storage as an intermediate step. This operation can be unnecessarily time-consuming.
For Hyper-V, SMB/CIFS storage is supported. Note that Zone-wide Primary Storage is not supported in Hyper-V.

section.para: If you intend to use only local disk for your installation, you can skip adding separate primary storage.
